hobby.message: You still tuning those antique typewriters?
What's your last origami fold say?

wrong_hobby_answer: That's not me. In free time, I collect antique typewriters. They remind me of a time when things were different.
neutral_answer: Colder, perhaps. Hard to say anymore.
I spend time repairing old typewriters. Reliable, unlike the news now.
Hard to find proper parts lately. Supply lines not what they were.
Best to keep busy, all the same.
The city feels different, if that's what you mean.
My hobby is restoring typewriters. Quiet work; keeps one thinking.
Used to find ribbons anywhere. These days, I scrape by with scraps.
Last week, market crowds made it impossible to get what I needed.
Tools are best kept to oneself now, I suppose.
Colder, yes. Or maybe just more unsettled.
Restoring antique typewriters is my habit. Small comforts in old machines.
Typebars sound steadier than most arguments on the street these days.
Weekends, I used to trade spare parts at the square.
With forums happening outside, hard to focus—too much noise for fine work.
Still, nothing steadies the mind like a repaired escapement spring.
Colder evenings, yes. Not just the air—something in the rhythm has changed.
I restore old typewriters. Manuals, ribbons, even carriage rails—work I grew up with.
Since the forums, crowds block the alleys where I get supplies.
Found a Remington ribbon in an abandoned box, but half the spools tangled.
Usually I write about what I hear, but lately, the noise makes it hard.
Sometimes I jot pieces about the council days—just for my drawer.
Funny, even the tap of the keys feels lonelier since Halden's passing.
You feel it too. The chill isn't just weather—it's memory settling in.
Restoring typewriters is my refuge. Each mechanism recalls a time before the Index.
I keep a journal on onion-skin paper, old habit from the Secretariat days.
Crowds from the forums spill beneath my window—makes quiet repairs difficult.
Last week, I missed a council memo in the commotion. First time since '22.
Even scavenging for springs or ribbons gets riskier—everyone is searching for stories, not parts.
Halden trusted my discretion. Now his absence haunts these pages more than I'd admit.
Stubborn thing, memory. You can’t oil away everything that sticks.
hobby_answer: Still working on a few machines, yes.
Mostly keep to myself these days.
Lot of noise outside lately, hard to focus.
I prefer routines, even when the city doesn’t cooperate.
Not much else to say.
Yes, I still tune typewriters now and then.
Harder lately with all the neighborhood gatherings outside.
Everyone’s sharing memories now, apparently for healing.
The noise carries. Not ideal for fine repairs.
Some things should stay private, in my opinion.
I manage, regardless of what’s trending.
I do, yes, still working on the antiques.
Lost a screw last week, hands got shaky from the shouting outside.
You can’t really restore detail work with the forums blaring through the walls.
Funny, fixing a typewriter while the world prefers talking.
Sometimes I listen, sometimes I close the curtains.
Still keep my notes handwritten.
It’s the only habit that’s stayed mine.
Absolutely, still tuning the old ones. Underwood’s my project right now.
It’s odd, though, with all those public forums under my window.
Everyone’s eager to share, but I prefer machines—they’re predictable, at least.
Last week, I had to stop repair work. Too much commotion outside.
The old keys need a steady hand, not loud voices.
There’s a comfort in restoring order—something the city’s missing.
I even wrote down a few overheard lines, just out of habit.
Funny how a hobby turns into a kind of witness.
Oh, always—antique typewriters outlast digital noise. Started as a joke in the Secretariat, really.
Lately the forums outside interrupt my work. Used to be, silence was reliable.
After Halden’s fall, people want to be heard. Makes the act of typing feel almost subversive now.
I stopped a tricky repair mid-way last week—couldn’t keep my hands steady with all that memory-sharing.
In the old days, I logged Council routines on these very keys. What I hear now—well, it’s a different archive.
Ended up scribbling down overheard confessions, just for myself.
I suppose I prefer the privacy of ink to the unpredictability outside.
Funny how my little machines, intended for control and order, now echo a city craving both.
Still, every sound from those forums finds its way between my lines these days.
